body.p:
Revd. & Dear Sir! It seems that you have no
regular correspondent in this city, for otherwise he
could give you matter enough, to have also "New Orleans"
mentioned in the domestic column of your valuable journal.
I take therefor the liberty to forward you some
short items, regarding religious affairs in New Orleans.

About two months ago Dr Illowy sent an
official letter to the Hebrew of this city, in which, he
requested them, not to circumcise in future any male
child born from a christian mother though the father
be an Israelite, for the following reasons:

1st/ It being evident that the circumcision is not performed
Hebrew but only for the purpose of being entitled to a
portion of ground on the Jewish burying place in case
of death, and according to the law, the ceremony of circum˶
cision can not be performed only Hebrew after which
the ceremony of Hebrew has to follow, while among all those

already circumcised children of christian mothers,
of whom some have already reached the age of
five and others of six years, is not one that had Hebrew
Though Dr Illowy explained to some of the
parents that their children can not be regarded as
by law as Israelite as long as Hebrew is not performed,
the father, but not the mother would yield to the exigen˶
cy of the law.

2ndly/ Since the circumcision is not performed Hebrew
the Hebrew not only that he acts contrary to the law,
but he also transgresses the prohibition Hebrew by making
a Hebrew

3rdly/ Suppose every thing would be done according to the
law both Hebrew and Hebrew, what however has Judaism to hope
of a child educated by a christian mother and an
irreligious father have we not enough Hebrew of our
own, who would not know that they are Jews were they
not circumcised what for should we yet, under the cover
of religion increase their number?

Dr Illowy made the above explanation to the
Board of Trustees who assisted him, and two of the
Hebrew who are members of the cong. were notified by them
that it is the desire of the Board that they would act

according to the decision of the Rabby, to which they
agreed. But the 3rd Hebrew wrote, two weeks after
he recieved Dr Illowy's answer letter, a very insulting
answer, in which he declared himself, that he has done so
before and will continue so, to circumcise all such
children born from christian mothers.

Dr Illowy after having recieved that insulting
answer of the Hebrew declared him publicly in the Synag.
as Hebrew having forfeited his right as Hebrew and being
in future unfit and unworthy for that holy office.

This event gave rise partly to a dissatisfaction among
the friends of the Hebrew, and those whose wive are strangers
Hebrew to our nation, and partly to a dispute among impartial
individuals about the correctness of Dr. I.'s decision.

Permit me therefor Revd Sir to lay before you and
your learned readers 3 questions

1st/ Is it permitted according to the law to circumcise
˶the son of a christian mother and an irreligious father
˶though we know aforehand that we have not a spark of hope
˶that the child will ever be brought up as a Jew?

2dly/ Suppose it be not permitted has any Rabby the right
˶to declare a Hebrew who acts contrary to his decision in
˶said question Hebrew and unfit in future to perform the
˶ceremony of circumcision?

3rdly/ Suppose the Rabby has such a right, to
˶declare a Hebrew, is then the Hebrew resting
˶ only upon the Hebrew, or is it likewise sinful of every
˶ individual who allows such a Hebrew to circumcise his child.

Hoping that you will grant these questions a space
in the columns of your valuable journal, and let us hear at the
same time your own opinion as well as those of other learned
men in Israel; I can assure you that by so doing you
will restore the peace into the hearts of those who are now
dissatisfied with the decision of Revd Dr Illowy.

Hebrew There were this year over fifty Hebrew in our
City, of which over forty were built by the members of
the Cong. "Schaarey Chased" Rampart St., whilst three
years ago when Dr I. arrived in this city there was not
more than one Hebrew built by the sexton of the Portoguese
Cong. in the yard of their Synag. Though it is true that
the Revd Gentleman worked indefatigably with patience
and perseverance to keep the word of God alive in his
community, still it must be admitted that praise enough
